moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nc3 e6 3. f4 d6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5: A little aggressive here, but this wins the centre and also frees up the bishop on c1
moves.5... cxd4 6. Nxd4 Be7 7. Bd3: Strengthening the centre, please note not only is white ahead on development, but he is already aiming his pieces toward where black's king will end up next move.
moves.7... O-O 8. Be3: This realistically only serves to strengthen the centre and allow the 0-0-0 later.
moves.8... a6: preparing the queenside pawn storm and also gives the bishop on c8 a chance to escape being blocked in by the f7 and e6 pawns.
moves.9. g4: White is a little reckless here and forgets about the bishop threat after e5, however even after black wins the pawn white gains the g file for his rook which will come to be rather painful in the later stages of the game.
moves.9... e5: trying to break up white's strong centre and win the pawn on g4
moves.10. fxe5 Bxg4 11. Qd2 dxe5 12. Nde2: the knight has no other good square to go to, f5 is a possibility but this allows the 0-0-0
moves.13. O-O-O: making the king safer and also allows the option of bringing the other rook into play
moves.14. Rhg1: bringing the rook onto the open g file, this is the start of white's attack, now the bishop on e3 starts to have some options
if white takes black is almost forced to take with the queen to prevent the king from being opened up entirely
moves.17... Nd4: Black decides to bring the other knight in to defend the kingside
moves.18. Qf2: white increases the pressure on the f6 bishop
moves.18... Kh8: freeing the pawn to defend the bishop
moves.19. Nxf6: black must now take with the queen to prevent bxg7+ kg8, bxf6#
